text.p: National Home Loans Holdings completed its financing for the year with the launch of a 448.4 million stg mortgage-backed FRN on Tuesday, finance director Nicholas Keen told Reuters.
"This completes our programme for the year. But we have a number of old transactions which we expect to refinance in the future, possibly early next year," he said.
Keen said the motivation for today's Homeloans No.3 Plc issue was two-fold: "It is partly to provide financing for our new mortgage loans, and also to refinance at more attractive rates."
Keen said the four-tranche structure was the most effective, given the mix of assets and range of investors being targeted. "The market has been looking for good quality sterling assets."
ING Barings and J.P. Morgan were joint lead managers on the class A1, A2 and B notes, while J.P. Morgan was sole lead manager on the class C notes.
Syndicate officials said there had not been much issuance in the sterling mortgage-backed sector this year.

"It (the bond) is principally the refinacing of various NHL originated securitisations which had been launched in around 1989/1990 and which had become expensive," a syndicate official at one of the joint leads said.
"This has cleaned up or tidied up a number of their older issues that were getting smaller and more expensive to run."
Keen said National Home Loans was also originating consumer loans, backed by car loans, with the intention to "mix them" with home loans.
On Monday, NHL Holdings conditionally agreed to buy a residential mortgage loan portfolio from an undisclosed British bank subsidiary for about 44 million stg.
Keen said that would also be refinanced in this bond.
Homeloans No. 3 follows Homeloans No. 1 issued in December 1995 -- a two-tranche 122.5 million stg FRN -- and Homeloans No. 2 this June -- a three-tranche 242.50 million stg FRN.
Today's deal comprised class A1 (135 million stg) and A2 notes (252.05 million stg), both rated Aaa by Moody's.
The A1 notes have an average life of 1.1 years, while the A2 notes have an average life of 4.8 years.
Class B notes (30.1 million stg) are rated A2 by Moody's and have an average life of 5.7 years. Class C notes (31.25 million stg) are rated Baa3 and have an average life of 5.7 years.
